docs.lead_paragraph: Salomon Adds Many Perks To Retain Junior Employees In a sign of changing times on Wall Street, Salomon Smith Barney is providing many perks to keep 500 junior employees from defecting to Internet companies.
docs.snippet: Salomon Adds Many Perks To Retain Junior Employees  In a sign of changing times on Wall Street, Salomon Smith Barney is providing many perks to keep 500 junior employees from defecting to Internet companies.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a move that could help hundreds of thousands of poor people, the Clinton administration ordered states today to restore Medicaid benefits to families who were improperly deprived of their health insurance when they left the welfare rolls. The action was announced by Donna E. Shalala, secretary of health and human services, who said many low-income people lost Medicaid coverage as an unintended consequence of the 1996 welfare law. In approving that law, Congress wanted to restrict eligibility for cash assistance while preserving access to Medicaid.

headline.main: States Told to Restore Improperly Cut Medicaid Benefits

docs.abstract: Clinton administration orders states to restore Medicaid benefits to families who were improperly deprived of their health insurance when they left welfare rolls; Donna E Shalala, secretary of health and human services, calls this unintended consequence of 1996 welfare law; advocates for poor see this as another step in gradual reversal of policy by Health and Human Servies officials, who initially denied there was serious problem; White House officials became concerned last year when they concluded that states' actions were contributing to significant increase in number of Americans without health insurance (M)
docs.snippet: In a move that could help hundreds of thousands of poor people, the Clinton administration ordered states today to restore Medicaid benefits to families who were improperly deprived of their health insurance when they left the welfare rolls.    The...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate approved today a $1.8 trillion budget plan for next year that seeks to restrain the growth of government and throws into sharp relief the bruising political battles between Congress and President Clinton in this election season. The Senate voted, 51 to 45, largely along party lines, to endorse a Republican-written budget blueprint that is nonbinding but is politically significant because it provides a framework for specific spending and tax bills for the fiscal year 2001, which begins Oct. 1.

headline.main: SENATE SETS STAGE FOR A MAJOR FIGHT WITH BUDGET PLAN

docs.abstract: Senate approves, 51 to 45, $1.8 trillion budget plan for next year that seeks to restrain growth of government and throws into sharp relief political battles between Congress and Pres Clinton; measure calls for increases in spending on military and education, cuts or freezes in many domestic programs, reduction in taxes by at least $150 billion over next five years, new $40 billion prescription drug benefit as part of Medicare, and paying down publicly held debt with surplus generated by Social Security; Senate measure must be reconciled with similar bill House passed on March 24 (M)
docs.snippet: The Senate approved today a $1.8 trillion budget plan for next year that seeks to restrain the growth of government and throws into sharp relief the bruising political battles between Congress and President Clinton in this election season.     The...

docs.lead_paragraph: Smokers Awarded Damages A Miami jury has awarded $6.9 million to two smokers in a class-action tobacco lawsuit, setting the stage for a huge punitive-damage award against the industry. PAGE A7

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: The House is preparing to vote on a bill that would permit independent physicians to bargain collectively with health plans -- in effect to form a union -- even though they do not work for a common employer or work together in any other way. This is a terrible idea. The bill would invite doctors to form cartels, jack up prices, boycott health plans and exploit consumers in ways that are permitted to no other independent businessmen in the economy. The legislation may induce physicians to pour contributions into the campaign chests of politicians during an election year, but patients would suffer the nasty consequences. That is why the Consumer Federation of America, the Department of Justice, the Federal Trade Commission and many leading antitrust authorities oppose the measure. The legislation, proposed by Tom Campbell, Republican of California, has already sailed through the Judiciary Committee. It would permit independent doctors to bargain collectively to negotiate fees and working conditions with health plans. The purpose of the bill, says Mr. Campbell, is to put doctors in a better position to negotiate better deals when they go up against huge health insurers.
docs.abstract: Editorial opposes Rep Tom Campbell's proposed bill that would permit independent physicians to bargain collectively with health plans, even though they do not work for common employer or work together in any other way; says bill would invite doctors to form cartels, jack up prices, boycott health plans and exploit consumers in ways that are permitted to no other independent businessmen in economy

docs.lead_paragraph: Back in the 50's Carol Burnett made her name as a nightclub performer with a song called ''I Made a Fool of Myself Over John Foster Dulles.'' If the Al Gore campaign had a theme song for the past week it might well be ''I Made a Fool of Myself Over Elian Gonzalez.'' But even Mr. Gore's craven act of political child abuse may not match the marathon foolishness of George W. Bush's self-immolating grudge match with the gay Log Cabin Republicans. ''It's really comical, if not farcical, it's so ridiculous,'' says Robert Stears, the chairman of Log Cabin's board. It's not clear, though, that it'll end happily. While the cold war being re-fought by proxy in Miami is increasingly ancient history as far as most Americans are concerned, Mr. Bush has stumbled into a lingering culture war that, while waning in much of the country, could well rage in the Republican Party through the convention and Election Day.

headline.main: Journal; La Cage au George W.

docs.abstract: Frank Rich Op-Ed column on Gov George W Bush's refusal to meet with gay Log Cabin Republicans; says his stated reason, that he does not agree with them, is hypocritical, given his willingness to meet with anti-Catholic bigots at Bob Jones University; says Bush's nonstop battle with his own party's major gay organization makes him, a self-styled 'compassionate conservative' and 'uniter not a divider,' increasingly look like hypocrite; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George W. Bush said today that he had invited a small group of gay Republicans to talk with him at the governor's mansion in Austin, Tex., next week, a development that stood in contrast to his longstanding refusal to meet formally with the Log Cabin Republicans, a leading gay political organization. The gay Republicans who are scheduled to visit the Texas governor are not representatives of the organization. In fact, a spokesman for the Log Cabin Republicans complained today that Mr. Bush would be sitting down with a hand-picked group of gay supporters as a way of avoiding the kind of substantive policy discussion that officials with the organization would like to have.

headline.main: Bush, in Reversal, to Meet With a Gay Republican Group

docs.abstract: Gov George W Bush says he invited small group of gay Republicans to talk with him at governor's mansion in Austin, Tex; development stands in contrast to his longstanding refusal to meet formally with Log Cabin Republicans, leading gay political organization; spokesman for Log Cabin Republicans complains that Bush plans to meet with hand-picked group of gay supporters as way of avoiding kind of substantive policy discussion that officials with organization would like to have; Bush's planned meeting hints at his desire to project more moderate image in general election than he did in primaries; photo (M)
